A Putin Strategy Emerges Recent diplomatic moves have shown that countering the Clinton administration's missile defense plan is clearly a priority for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
South Africa AIDS Crisis South Africa is trying to reconcile its Constitution with an AIDS crisis in the face of a challenge to its practice of disqualifying gay men from giving blood.

Women's Rights Backed at U.N. A week-long meeting for women ended at the United Nations, preserving a range of women's rights with no significant victories for opponents who have spent the last five years trying to reverse the gains made at a watershed conference in Beijing.
Lebanon to Send Troops The Lebanese government will send 500 troops to the southern part of the country recently evacuated by Israel.
(AFP)
NATIONAL

Voter Initiatives Seek Health Insurance Overhaul A coalition of doctors, nurses and others are expected this weekend to collect the remaining signatures needed to place before Massachusetts voters what experts call the most sweeping health care referendum on any state's ballot this fall. The referendum would require the Legislature to find a way to provide health insurance coverage for all.

Death Row Record a Concern New lawyers for Gary Graham, who is on death row in Texas, say he is innocent and are seeking to have Gov. George W. Bush grant him some form of clemency. Mr. Graham's lawyers portray his case as a textbook example of how bad lawyering sends poor people to death row.
Crackdown on Doctor Training The authorities who evaluate medical education have begun to crack down on training programs that force interns and residents to work excessively long hours.

G.O.P. on the Counterattack The Republican Party, responding to an advertising campaign by the Democrats, unveiled its first national commercial, detailing Gov. George W. Bush's proposals for overhauling Social Security.
NEW YORK/REGION

Meaning Is Questioned In Standardized Test Scores Scores achieved by students in New York City's schools on two standardized tests showed significant improvement recently, but whether the year-to-year ups-and-downs of such results are meaningful is open to question.
